document.docAuthor: Fontana, Tayara, Cóndor-Luján, Báslavi, Azevedo, Fernanda, Pérez, Thierry & Klautau, Michelle
document.masterDocTitle: Diversity and distribution patterns of Calcareous sponges (subclass Calcinea) from Martinique

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Diversity and distribution patterns of Calcareous sponges (subclass Calcinea) from Martinique

bibRefCitation.refString: Haeckel, E. (1872) Die Kalkschwamme, eine Monographie. G. Reimer, Berlin, 418 pp.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Synonyms.
Artynas clathria : Haeckel 1872 : 159
,
Heteropegma nodusgordii : Poléjaeff 1883: 45
, Hanitsch 1895 : 209.
Leucaltis clathria : Haeckel 1872 : 159
, Dendy 1913: 16, Arndt 1940 : 46, Borojevic & Peixinho 1976 : 1002, Borojevic 1998 : 75,
Borojevic et al. 2002
: 1148, Muricy et al. 2008: 131,
Lanna et al. 2009
: 13, Muricy et al. 2011: 35,
Klautau et al. 2013
: 449, Van Soest 2017: 198,
Cóndor-Luján et al . 2018
: 61.

materialsCitation.collectorName: Le Rocher du Diamant & F. Azevedo

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Material Examined. ( One specimen) UFRJPOR 7671,
Le Rocher du Diamant
, Martinique ( 14°26.556' N – 61°2.408' W ), collected by F. Azevedo ,
25 April 2015
,
18.8 m
depth.

subSubSection.paragraph: Colour. Light pink alive and white in ethanol.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 11. Spicule measurements of
Leucaltis clathria
(UFRJPOR 7671).

FIGURE 11.
Leucaltis clathria
(UFRJPOR 7671). A. Specimen in situ . B. Specimen in ethanol. C . Larvae in the choanosome. D. Cross-section showing tangential cortical triactines and a large tetractine whose apical actine crosses the choanosome and penetrates the atrium. E. SEM micrograph of a tangential section of the atrial wall with sagittal triactines and tetractines and with two apical actines of cortical tetractines protruding into the atrium. F. SEM micrograph of a tangential section of the atrial wall showing sagittal triactines and tetractines. G. Choanosomal skeleton composed of small regular triactines and tetractines.

subSubSection.paragraph: Triactine I: Regular. Very variable in size. Actines are conical with sharp tips ( Figure 12A ). Size: 330.0– 720.0/40.0–75.0 µm.

Triactine II: Regular or sagittal. Actines are cylindrical, with blunt or rounded tips ( Figures 11F , 12D ). Size: 52.5–65.0/2.5–5.0 µm (regular), 30.0–67.5/2.5–5.0 µm (sagittal, unpaired actine), 57.5–70.0/2.5–5.0 µm (sagittal, paired actines).

Tetractine II: Regular or sagittal. Actines are cylindrical with blunt or rounded tips ( Figures 11F , 12E ). Size: 30.0–62.5/2.5–3.7 µm (regular), 32.5–52.5/2.5–5.0 µm (sagittal, unpaired actine), 37.5–72.5/2.5–5.0 µm (sagittal, paired actine).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 12.
Leucaltis clathria
(UFRJPOR 7671). A. Triactine I. B. Tetractine I. C. Apical actine of a tetractine I (arrow). D. Sagittal triactine II. E. Sagittal tetractine II.

subSubSection.paragraph: Ecology. The analysed specimen was collected at the entrance of a cave, in a shaded environment. No epibionts were found.

Geographical distribution . Atlantic Ocean: U.S.A. Florida ( Haeckel 1872 ), off Bermuda (Poléjaeff 1883),
Panama
(
Klautau et al. 2013
), Portugal ( Hanitsch 1895 ; Arndt 1940 ), Guyana Shelf (Van Soest 2017), Brazil— Pará State, Alagoas State, Ceará State,
Rio Grande do Norte
State, Sergipe State, Espírito Santo State ( Borojevic & Peixinho 1976 ; Muricy et al . 2008; 2011,
Lanna et al . 2009
).

Remarks. For a long time,
Leucaltis clathria
was considered to be a cosmopolitan species (Poléjaeff 1883; Carter 1886 ; Dendy 1892 , 1893 , 1905 ; Borojevic 1998 , Borojevic & Klautau 2000 ). However, in 2013 Klautau et al. generated DNA sequences of
L. clathria
from the Caribbean Sea ( type locality of this species) and from Australia , and suggested that the specimens from Australia comprised a distinct species. In 2015, Van Soest & De Voogd published a work about calcareous sponges from Indonesia and proposed that Indo-Pacific specimens morphologically similar to
L. clathria
should be called
L. nodusgordii (Poléjaeff, 1883)
. Therefore,
L. clathria
is currently considered to be present only in the Atlantic Ocean, having an amphi-Atlantic distribution.
